importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article reflects the current state of food supply conditions in Gaza as of late October 2025, highlighting ongoing humanitarian challenges following the ceasefire.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame shows the period during which the US-brokered ceasefire has been active, and humanitarian aid efforts have been scaled up, though still insufficient.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are significantly below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, currently at about 750 metric tonnes per day.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara (Kerem Shalom and Kissufim) — are operational, restricting aid flow.
The WFP has 26 food distribution points open, up from five, but still far below the target of 145 distribution points across Gaza.
Humanitarian aid is reaching northern Gaza via the south, but large-scale convoys to Gaza City and the north remain absent due to lack of access and security restrictions.
The Rafah border crossing with Egypt remains closed, pending Hamas' return of deceased captives' bodies.
Hamas has so far handed over 13 of the 28 pledged captives' remains, with two more delivered as of the reporting date.
Residents are rationing food and storing supplies due to uncertainty about the ceasefire's longevity.
The WFP emphasizes that sustained ceasefire and full opening of crossings are vital to preventing famine and saving lives in Gaza.
The US president’s 20-point plan includes the promise of full humanitarian aid, which is still not being fully realized on the ground.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international humanitarian agency that coordinates food distribution to areas facing severe food insecurity.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to monitoring and reporting on food supply levels in Gaza, providing official assessments of the humanitarian crisis and urging greater access to crossings.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Israel and Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two active crossings into Gaza, allowing limited food and aid entry into the Strip.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing in central Gaza, used for humanitarian deliveries.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing is one of only two operational routes into Gaza, severely limiting the volume and reach of food aid.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its closure restricts potential aid access from Egypt and limits humanitarian supply routes into northern Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister, who has made statements about the Rafah crossing and ceasefire conditions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has publicly stated that the Rafah crossing will remain closed until Hamas returns the bodies of deceased captives, directly affecting aid access.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and military organization with control over Gaza, involved in negotiations over prisoner releases.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas has committed to return the bodies of deceased captives, which is a condition for reopening the Rafah crossing and enabling broader humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President, who brokered a ceasefire and proposed a 20-point plan for ending the war in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His diplomatic initiative created the ceasefire framework that enabled current aid deliveries, though aid remains below target due to restricted access points.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major road in Gaza that runs north-south and is critical for aid distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted permission to use this main artery for deliveries, limiting access to northern Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas responsible for military operations and public statements.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They announced the handover of two more Israeli captives' remains, signaling progress in prisoner exchange talks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically short, with only 750 metric tonnes of food entering daily — far below the 2,000-tonne target — due to just two operational border crossings: Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara. Despite an increase from five to 26 distribution points, access remains severely limited, especially in the north, where the Salah al-Din Street has not been opened. The Rafah crossing with Egypt remains closed, pending Hamas’ return of the remains of deceased captives. The US-brokered ceasefire, supported by President Donald Trump’s 20-point plan, is seen as essential to sustaining humanitarian access, but current conditions indicate a dire lack of aid and ongoing uncertainty about the ceasefire’s future. Palestinians are rationing food and storing supplies due to fears of renewed conflict.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
